content: Does anyone know a word for this concept in order theory? I have a monotone function f:P→Qf : P \to Qf:P→Q and it is not just surjective but for any q≤q′q \leq q'q≤q′ in QQQ there exists p≤p′p \leq p'p≤p′ in PPP such that f(p)=qf(p) = qf(p)=q and f(p′)=q′f(p') = q'f(p′)=q′. It's not the same as being a full functor because the ppp depends on both qqq and q′q'q′.
In fact my example is not full: there are cases where f(p)≤f(p′)f(p) \leq f(p')f(p)≤f(p′) but not p≤p′p \leq p'p≤p′

This is equivalent to saying that

  • fff is surjective, and
  • fff maps lower sets to lower sets.

Indeed, take q≤q′q \leq q'q≤q′, by surjectiveness there exists p′p'p′ with q′=f(p′)q' = f(p')q′=f(p′), and since the image of the lower set of p′p'p′ is the lower set of f(p′)f(p')f(p′), there must exist p≤p′p \leq p'p≤p′ such that f(p)=qf(p) = qf(p)=q.

I would simply call the second condition being a closed map, since lower sets are the closed sets for the Alexandrov topology on the poset.
Nice! Now that I've seen your formulation it also looks like a fibration condition? I.e., if q≤f(p′)q \leq f(p')q≤f(p′) then there exists p≤p′p \leq p'p≤p′ with f(p)=qf(p) = qf(p)=q
But I don't think my example is a fibration so something must be wrong
I don't think Max's condition implies that fff maps lower sets to lower sets. If I read it correctly, not just ppp but also p′p'p′ can depend on both qqq and q′q'q′.
I guess in category theory terminology this would be saying that the induced functor on the arrow categories is essentially surjective?
I believe these are precisely the descent morphisms in the category of posets -- that is the pullback-stable quotient maps. See here for more details.

Mike Shulman said:

I don't think Max's condition implies that fff maps lower sets to lower sets. If I read it correctly, not just ppp but also p′p'p′ can depend on both qqq and q′q'q′.

Oh, that's true.

Max New said:

Does anyone know a word for this concept in order theory? I have a monotone function f:P→Qf : P \to Qf:P→Q and it is not just surjective but for any q≤q′q \leq q'q≤q′ in QQQ there exists p≤p′p \leq p'p≤p′ in PPP such that f(p)=qf(p) = qf(p)=q and f(p′)=q′f(p') = q'f(p′)=q′. It's not the same as being a full functor because the ppp depends on both qqq and q′q'q′.

This looks like something modal logicians and people studying (traditional) Kripke semantics of intuitionistic logic would know and have a name for.

Max New said:

Does anyone know a word for this concept in order theory? I have a monotone function f:P→Qf : P \to Qf:P→Q and it is not just surjective but for any q≤q′q \leq q'q≤q′ in QQQ there exists p≤p′p \leq p'p≤p′ in PPP such that f(p)=qf(p) = qf(p)=q and f(p′)=q′f(p') = q'f(p′)=q′. It's not the same as being a full functor because the ppp depends on both qqq and q′q'q′.

it seems natural to call it order-surjective. and then g:Q→Rg:Q\to Rg:Q→R would be order-injective if for any x≤x′x\leq x'x≤x′ and y≤y′y\leq y'y≤y′ in QQQ holds that whenever g(x)=g(y)g(x)=g(y)g(x)=g(y) and g(x′)=g(y′)g(x')=g(y')g(x′)=g(y′) then x=yx=yx=y and x′=y′x'=y'x′=y′. hmm.

call f:P→Qf:P\to Qf:P→Q preorder-surjective if f:Pf→Qf:P_f\to Qf:Pf​→Q is order-surjective, where PfP_fPf​ is the preorder with the underlying set PPP but obtained as the transitive closure of PPP under x∼y  ⟺  f(x)=f(y)x\sim y \iff f(x)=f(y)x∼y⟺f(x)=f(y). then the preorder-surjective and order-injective maps form a factorization system.

i am sure someone somewhere must have used it. to decompose a monotone day...

but it gets interesting to lift to categories. is there a universal way to make an arbitrary functor conservative by adding unique isomorphisms to the domain category?

dusko said:

is there a universal way to make an arbitrary functor conservative by adding unique isomorphisms to the domain category?

I believe the class of conservative functors is the right class of a factorization system on Cat\rm CatCat, whose left class is the "iterated localizations" obtained by repeatedly adding formal inverses to morphisms. So in particular you can factor an arbitrary functor as an iterated localization followed by a conservative functor. Is that what you have in mind?

Graham Manuell said:

I believe these are precisely the descent morphisms in the category of posets -- that is the pullback-stable quotient maps. See here for more details.

Nice! Yes, it's Proposition 2.5 in the paper you cite.

[sorry, this is the answer to mike shulman.]

no. there is the obvious lifting of order-surjections to categories. i am asking how to extend them to a factorization system.

we just saw that order surjectons on posets become epis of a factorization system if we force them to be conservative.

in other words: if the monics are essentially surjective faithful functors, who are the epis?
